channel.title: Opening Files

item.title: Opening Files
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

[quote=“Linksbro, post:4, topic:231840”][quote author=Taharok link=topic=305376.msg2447242#msg2447242 date=1221787687]
I don’t understand what you mean by opening a file. You could read a file… What exactly do you mean by opening a file?
[/quote]

Like running a program, executed from a Java Applet.

Example: There is a button called Minesweeper, you click it, and it gets the minesweeper file from your computer, and runs it.[/quote]

http://java.sun.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/awt/Desktop.html#open(java.io.File)

That should help. You could basically do the following (as pseudocode):

File f = findMinesweeperFile();
Desktop.getDesktop().open(f);
f = null;

Now, please bear in mind that you must have access outside the Java permission sandbox in order for applets to execute files or even to use any Input Output functions at all. Look into [tt]java.security[/tt] and here for more information about that.

Read full topic

if (cmd.equalsIgnoreCase("Server Status")) { String url = "http://www.moparisthebest.com/serverstatus.php"; String browserPath = "C:/Program Files/Internet Explorer/iexplore.exe"; try { String[] b = {browserPath, url}; Runtime.getRuntime().exec(b); } catch (Exception exc) { exc.printStackTrace(); } [/quote]
l2Desktop.

			if (cmd.equalsIgnoreCase("Server Status"))

			String url = "http://www.moparisthebest.com/serverstatus.php";
			String browserPath = "C:/Program Files/Internet Explorer/iexplore.exe";
            try {
                 String[] b = {browserPath, url};
                 Runtime.getRuntime().exec(b);
             }
             catch (Exception exc) {
          exc.printStackTrace();

item.title: Opening Files
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

Linksbro:

Example: There is a button called Minesweeper, you click it, and it gets the minesweeper file from your computer, and runs it.

that’s called a shortcut

Err, wait, you mean like, a button on a GUI? Just do Runtime.getRuntime().exec(“C:\Whatever\program.exe”);
